definition: Bidirectional Scattering Distribution Function. A generalization that combines BRDF (reflection) and BTDF (transmission) to describe how light interacts with a surface.
Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function. A function that defines how light is reflected off a surface, depending on the incoming and outgoing light directions.
Bounding Volume Hierarchy. A tree data structure used to accelerate ray-object intersection tests by organizing scene geometry into nested bounding boxes.

The process of removing noise from a rendered image, typically Monte Carlo noise from undersampled path tracing. Modern denoisers use neural networks (e.g., Intel Open Image Denoise, NVIDIA OptiX AI denoiser).
Global Illumination. Lighting algorithms that account for indirect light (light that has bounced off surfaces) in addition to direct illumination, producing more realistic images.
High Dynamic Range Image. An image format that stores a wider range of luminance values than standard images. Commonly used as environment maps for image-based lighting in 3D scenes.

A class of algorithms that use random sampling to estimate numerical results. In rendering, Monte Carlo integration is the foundation of path tracing — rays are sampled randomly to estimate the rendering equation.

Neural Radiance Field. A method that uses a neural network to represent a 3D scene as a continuous volumetric function mapping 3D coordinates to color and density. Trained from a set of posed photographs.

Physically Based Rendering. An approach to rendering that models materials and light transport according to physical principles, producing more consistent and realistic results than ad-hoc shading models.

Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio. An image quality metric measured in decibels (dB) that compares a rendered image to a reference. Higher values indicate less error. Typical ranges for rendered images: 30–50 dB.

Signed Distance Field (or Function). A function that returns the shortest distance from any point in space to the nearest surface. Positive outside, negative inside. Used for ray marching, procedural modeling, and real-time effects.

Samples Per Pixel. The number of ray samples averaged for each pixel in a Monte Carlo renderer. More samples reduce noise but increase render time. Typical values range from 64 (noisy preview) to 4096+ (final quality).
Structural Similarity Index Measure. An image quality metric that compares structural patterns, luminance, and contrast between two images. Values range from 0 to 1, where 1 means identical images.
